resources.string:
Clauses are essential components of sentences, and mastering them is crucial for developing strong writing skills. 

In this lesson, we will cover the basics of independent and dependent clauses, various types of dependent clauses, and how to use them in sentences. 

By the end of this workbook, you'll be able to craft more complex and engaging sentences. 

Let's get started! 

A clause is a group of words that contains a subject and a verb. 

It can either stand alone as a complete thought (independent clause) or rely on another clause to make sense (dependent clause). 

EN7G-II-a-1 
Use phrases, clauses, and sentences appropriately and meaningfully. 

EN8WC-Id-1.1.6 
Organize ideas in one-step word, phrase, and sentence outline forms.

Main Clauses 

Examples: 

"I love reading books." 

"He played basketball." 

Main clauses are clauses that can stand alone as complete sentences. In the first example, "I love reading books," the subject ("I") and the verb ("love reading books") create a complete thought that can be a sentence on its own. The same applies to the second example, "He played basketball."

Subordinating Clauses 

Examples: 

"Although it rained" 

"Because she was tired" 

Subordinating clauses are clauses that cannot stand alone as complete sentences. In the first example, "Although it rained," we have the subordinating conjunction "Although" that makes it a dependent clause. It needs more information to complete the thought. The second example, "Because she was tired," also relies on additional information to make sense as it starts with the subordinating conjunction "Because."

Types of Dependent Clauses 

Adjective Clauses 

Examples: 

""The book that I borrowed from the library is fascinating." 

"The girl who won the race is my sister." 

Adjective clauses provide additional information about nouns in sentences. In the first example, "that I borrowed from the library" describes which book we're talking about. In the second example, "who won the race" provides more information about the girl. These clauses function like adjectives, adding details to the nouns they modify.

Adverbial Clauses 

Examples: 

"She studied hard because she wanted to pass the exam." 

"He ran quickly so that he could catch the bus." 

Adverbial clauses modify verbs, adjectives, or adverbs. In the first example, "because she wanted to pass the exam" explains why she studied hard, modifying the verb "studied." In the second example, "so that he could catch the bus" tells us the purpose of running quickly, modifying the verb "ran."

A noun clause is a clause (a group of words with a subject and a verb) that serves as a noun in a sentence. It is a dependent clause and cannot function alone as a complete sentence. To work properly, it must be part of a larger sentence to form a complete thought. 
In other words, a noun clause has a subject and a predicate, like a sentence, but because it is dependent, it doesn\â€™t express a complete thought. 
A Noun clause usually begins with words such as "what," "why," "who," "when," "how," or "that," and can be used to provide more information about a noun in the sentence. 

Examples: 
My mom helped me decide which school should I enroll in. 
The most wonderful thing I admired about my teachers is that they are so brilliant. 
What my parent said helped me to become the person I am now.
